title: 104_hr3008
content: The "Helium Privatization Act of 1996" is cited in this Act. Amendments to the Helium Act are specified, and the authority of the Secretary is outlined in sections 3, 4, and 5. The Secretary may enter agreements with private parties for helium recovery and disposal on Federal lands, granting leasehold rights and subject to regulations. Helium sales are limited to parties with recovery agreements. The Secretary may store, transport, and sell helium in accordance with the Helium Privatization Act of 1996, subject to existing agreements with Federal oil and gas lessees. The Secretary can store, transport, and sell helium under the Helium Privatization Act of 1996, following agreements with Federal oil and gas lessees. The Secretary is authorized to store, transport, and withdraw crude helium under the Helium Privatization Act of 1996. Within 18 months of the Act's enactment, the Secretary must cease production, refining, and marketing of refined helium. Additionally, the Secretary is required to dispose of facilities related to helium activities, except for storage facilities. The Secretary must designate and dispose of excess property related to helium activities within 24 months after cessation of activities. The disposal must comply with the Federal Property and Administrative Services Act of 1949, and proceeds from the sale of such property will be treated as moneys received under this chapter. All costs related to the sale, disposal, and termination of personnel, as well as the cessation of activities, will be paid from the helium production fund. An exception is made for facilities and equipment necessary for helium storage, transportation, and quality control in the Bureau of Mines Cliffside Field. Existing contracts must be honored. Contracts for purchasing refined helium from the Secretary will remain in force until refining operations cease. Costs for contract termination will be covered by the helium production fund. The Secretary imposes fees on individuals for helium storage, transportation, and withdrawal services to cover full costs. Fees received are considered moneys under the Act. The amendment to subsection 6 of the Act requires persons to have enforceable contracts to purchase crude helium from the Secretary. Sales of crude helium will be determined by the Secretary in consultation with the helium industry to minimize market disruption. Sales of crude helium will be repaid as required. The amendment requires the Secretary to sell crude helium at a price determined by dividing the outstanding repayable amounts by the volume of helium owned by the US and adjusting for inflation. Moneys received from helium sales on federal lands will go to the Secretary. The Secretary must sell crude helium at a price determined by dividing outstanding repayable amounts by the volume of helium owned by the US and adjusting for inflation. Moneys received from helium sales on federal lands will be paid to the Treasury and credited against amounts required to be repaid. Subsection 6(e) is repealed, and subsection 6(f) is amended to specify the transfer of excess funds to the Treasury after the disposal of certain facilities. Upon repayment of all amounts, the fund established under this section will be terminated, and all moneys received under this Act will be deposited in the general fund. Moneys received under this Act will be deposited in the general fund of the Treasury. SEC. 5. ELIMINATION OF STOCKPILE. Section 8 is amended to read as follows: "SEC. 8. ELIMINATION OF STOCKPILE." The Secretary will start selling crude helium from US reserves by January 1, 2005, to dispose of excess reserves by January 1, 2015. Sales will be determined by the Secretary in consultation with the industry to minimize market disruption and ensure repayment to the Treasury. The Secretary must repay amounts to the Treasury under section 6(c) regardless of discovering additional helium reserves. SEC. 6. REPEAL OF AUTHORITY TO BORROW. Sections 12 and 15 are repealed. SEC. 7. LAND CONVEYANCE IN POTTER COUNTY, TEXAS. The Secretary of the Interior will transfer land in Potter County, Texas to the Texas Plains Girl Scout Council for $1, with easements reserved for pipeline rights-of-way. The land is described as the East Three Hundred Thirty-One (E331) acres out of Section Seventy-eight (78) in Block Nine (9), B.S. & F. Survey. The metes and bounds description of the land in Vol. 66A of the Patent Records of the State of Texas includes a tract of 171 acres known as the North part of the East part of survey Seventy-eight (78). It starts at a stone marked X set by W.D. Twichell in 1905 and follows specific directions to delineate the boundaries of the land. The metes and bounds description of the land in Vol. 66A of the Patent Records of the State of Texas includes a tract of 171 acres known as the North part of the East part of survey Seventy-eight (78). It starts at a stone marked X set by W.D. Twichell in 1905 and follows specific directions to delineate the boundaries of the land. The second tract consists of 160 acres described by metes and bounds starting at the Southwest corner of Section 59 and following specific directions to define the boundaries. The land described in the metes and bounds description covers an area of 331 acres. The boundaries are defined by specific directions, starting from the Southeast corner of the West half of Section 78, then moving North, East, and finally back to the starting point. SEC. 8. REPORT ON HELIUM. The Secretary must arrange a study with the National Academy of Sciences to assess the impact of helium reserve disposal on US interests before offering crude helium for sale. A report must be submitted to Congress 18 months before the sale, including the National Academy's findings and the Secretary's conclusions after consulting with industry and federal agencies. The Secretary must consult with relevant agencies to determine if selling the helium reserve will harm US interests. If adverse effects are found, recommendations for legislation must be made to prevent such impacts. The House of Representatives passed the legislation on April 30, 1996. Attest: ROBIN H. CARLE, Clerk.
